title: 113_s2529
content: The Act is titled the "National All Schedules Prescription Electronic Reporting Reauthorization Act of 2014" and it amends the purpose. The National All Schedules Prescription Electronic Reporting Act of 2005 is amended to establish State-controlled substance monitoring systems. This aims to provide health care providers with timely prescription history information to identify patients at risk for addiction and allow law enforcement access for regulatory purposes. The National All Schedules Prescription Electronic Reporting Act of 2005 is amended to establish State-controlled substance monitoring systems, providing prescription history information for investigating drug diversion and monitoring prescribing practices. AMENDMENTS TO CONTROLLED SUBSTANCE MONITORING PROGRAM. Section 399O of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include maintaining and operating an existing State-controlled substance monitoring program. The Secretary is required to establish minimum requirements for criteria used by States for specific purposes. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include maintaining and operating a State-controlled substance monitoring program. States must meet minimum requirements for criteria and incorporate prescription drug monitoring program data into health information technology. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include integrating prescription drug monitoring program data into health information technology systems for prescribers and dispensers. This ensures timely access to patients' controlled prescription drug history and enhances public health or public safety. The Public Health Service Act is amended to integrate prescription drug monitoring program data into health information technology systems for prescribers and dispensers, ensuring timely access to patients' controlled prescription drug history and enhancing public health and safety. The State submitting the program must describe how it will achieve interoperability with health information technology systems and include timelines for implementation. The Secretary will monitor these efforts. The Secretary will monitor State efforts to achieve interoperability with health information technology systems. Funds returned will be redistributed among remaining grantees according to a specified formula. The State must comply with establishing, improving, or maintaining a controlled substance monitoring program under this section. They should report on interoperability with the controlled substance monitoring program of Federal agencies, focusing on public health or public safety. The State must establish, improve, or maintain a controlled substance monitoring program, reporting on interoperability with Federal agencies. The State receiving a grant must provide aggregate data to the Secretary for evaluation and reporting purposes. Other entities may access nonidentifiable information for research purposes. The State receiving a grant must facilitate prescriber and dispenser use of the controlled substance monitoring system and educate them on its benefits. Subsection (k) is redesignated as subsection (i). In subsection (k)(2)(A), clauses (ii) and (iii) are amended to ensure linkages to substance use disorder services and health information technology systems. Subsection (l)(1) is revised to include maintenance. Subsection (m)(8) now includes commonwealths and territories of the United States. In subsection (m)(8), commonwealths and territories of the United States are now included. Authorization of Appropriations is set at $7,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2014 to 2018.
